definition: abbr. for Xinjiang 新疆[Xin1 jiang1] or Singapore 新加坡[Xin1 jia1 po1]/surname Xin

sentences.english: It is a funky restaurant with very interesting art on the walls.
sentences.chinese: 那是一家牆上掛着很成心思的繪畫的新潮餐館。

sentences.english: You will be a boy if you some fashionable clothes.
sentences.chinese: 如果你穿些新潮的衣服打扮一下，你會是個帥小夥。

sentences.english: The Group of New Trend is a pearl which has been forgot.
sentences.chinese: 新潮社是一顆被遺忘的金沙驪珠。

sentences.english: Unique design, comprihensive top furniture supermarket, leading the new fashion of furniture consumption.
sentences.chinese: 匠心獨具，百貨式高端家居賣場，引領消費新潮流。

sentences.english: It is designed to be a hipper less expensive version of the Prius.
sentences.chinese: 它的設計是一個新潮的，便宜的普銳斯的版本。

sentences.english: Bibo shake shadow dream hunt, chase trendy brothel visitors.
sentences.chinese: 碧波搖影尋舊夢，青樓遊客追新潮。

sentences.english: Sorching midsummer, choosing a few trendy sunglass is first selection important matter.
sentences.chinese: 炎炎盛夏，選幾款新潮的太陽鏡是首選大事。

sentences.english: Or rather, it's "a new trend in Chinese society".
sentences.chinese: 甚至，這很可能是“中國社會的一個新潮流”。

sentences.english: Magic is new and fashionable to a lot of young people.
sentences.chinese: 對於很多年輕人來說，魔術就是一種時尚新潮流。

sentences.english: A martini defined cool and modern.
sentences.chinese: 馬提尼代表着酷和新潮。

sentences.english: "Snowboarding is much newer than skiing, " he said.
Wheelie: I tell you, this guy did not age well.
sentences.chinese: 告訴你，這傢伙還挺新潮。

sentences.english: She kept rhapsodizing about your new fashions.
sentences.chinese: 她不住地熱烈讚揚你的新潮服裝。

sentences.english: I’m all for staying hip and relevant.
sentences.chinese: 我完全贊成要保持激情與新潮。

sentences.english: Look, isn't this belt just so stylin'?
sentences.chinese: 看，這條皮帶有夠新潮吧？

sentences.english: The trendy rock group was only a flash - in - the - pan.
sentences.chinese: 新潮搖滾樂隊只是曇花一現。

definition: to return to old ways (a Confucian aspiration)/to turn back the clock/neoclassical school during Tang and Song associated with classical writing 古文/retro (fashion style based on nostalgia, esp. for 1960s)
to make a show of being original or unconventional (idiom)
lit. new bud/fig. new and original
to keep up with the latest fashion
new generation of youths (generation X, Y etc)
to mix and match (of clothing etc)
